creditline: Lent by Richard and Diana Rose
description: red, yellow, green, blue, black; desk-style phone with cradle for hand set; comprised of lego blocks; hand set is detached, with black spiral cord attatched to it; 14 separate lego blocks accompany phone; drawer pulls out to R to hold loose blocks
text: Popularly (but perhaps improperly) known as the "Lego" phone, this playful design was aimed at young and old.  Produced in a Lego-like casing, it featured a side drawer to accommodate loose Legos to toy with while chatting on the phone.  Did you know that two bricks with eight studs can be combined in 24 different ways; four bricks yield 1,060 combinations; and six bricks more than 100 million'  From the '60s through '80s, the emphasis in telephone design dramatically shifted from instruments of necessity to entertainment devices.
title: "Super Blocks" push-button telephone
